anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 22, 1952 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 66 of 1952 arising out of the decree dated March 7, 1952 of Bombay High Court in its Ordinary Original Civil Jurisdiction in Suit No. 1177 of 1951.

The suit giving rise to this appeal is based on section 3 1   d  of the Bombay Hindu Divorce Act, XXII of 1947,  which hereinafter will be referred to as The Act  which came into force on May 12, 1947, the date the Governors assent was published in the Bombay Government Gazette.

anchor.surface_text: What is desertion? Rayden on Divorce which is a standard Work on the subject at p. 128  6th Edn.  has summarised the case-law on the subject in these terms- Desertion is the separation of one spouse from the other, with an intention on the part of the deserting spouse of bringing companyabitation permanently to on end without reasonable cause and without the companysent of the other spouse but the physical act of departure by one spouse does number necessarily make that spouse the deserting party.

anchor.surface_text: The most important part of the letter is... our client has become entitled to obtain a divorce and our client does not desire to keep you any longer under his care and protection... makes it clear that... the plaintiff had positively come to the determination...

arguments.claim: Telegram Ex. B and letters of Nov 1947 show plaintiff not consenting to wife's return.

arguments.claim: Defendant stayed with plaintiff's family at Patan multiple times, inconsistent with desertion.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is further supported by the fact that between 1948 and 1951 the defendant stayed with her mother-in-law at Patan... This conduct is wholly inconsistent with the plaintiffs case that the defendant was in desertion...

arguments.claim: Plaintiff could have called his parents to corroborate but did not; his evidence falls short.

anchor.surface_text: There is no explanation why the plaintiff could not examine his father and mother in corroboration... As the plaintiffs evidence on many important aspects... falls short of proving his case...

arguments.claim: No presumption of continued desertion as initial desertion not proved.

holdings.text: The plaintiff has failed to prove the offence of desertion by the defendant beyond all reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: It is also well settled that in proceedings for divorce the plaintiff must prove the offence of desertion, like any other matrimonial offence, beyond all reasonable doubt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Events of May 24, 1947 consistent with both parties' versions; lack of corroboration for plaintiff's uncorroborated testimony; solicitor's letter indicates plaintiff's unwillingness.

holdings.text: The happenings of May 24, 1947 are consistent with both conflicting theories and do not prove desertion.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether her leaving her marital home on the afternoon of May 24, 1947, is only consistent with her having deserted... That is the plaintiffs case. May that conduct be not consistent with the defendants case...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendant's departure explainable as shamefaced flight after discovery of letter Ex. E, not permanent abandonment; no exclusive consistency with animus deserendi.

holdings.text: No constructive desertion by the plaintiff; defendant's claim of being forcibly turned out uncorroborated.

anchor.surface_text: If her case that she bad been forcibly turned out of her marital home by the husband had been made out, certainly the husband would have been guilty of constructive desertion, because the test is riot who left the matrimonial home first.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of these two witnesses on behalf of the defendant is ample corroboration... We therefore do not see any sufficient reasons for brushing aside all that oral evidence...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corroborated by relatives' testimony (father, cousin); consistent with natural events; stays with in-laws inconsistent with desertion.

holdings.text: Solicitor's letter Ex. A indicates plaintiff unwilling to resume cohabitation and affirm marriage.

anchor.surface_text: The most important part of the letter is... our client has become entitled to obtain a divorce and our client does not desire to keep you any longer under his care and protection... makes it clear that... the plaintiff had positively come to the determination...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter states plaintiff entitled to divorce and does not desire to keep wife; no allegation of her desertion; plaintiff's explanations unconvincing.

holdings.text: No animus deserendi proved on part of defendant.

anchor.surface_text: For the offence of desertion, so far as the deserting spouse is concerned, two essential conditions must be there., namely,  1  the factum of separation, and  2  the intention to bring cohabitation permanently to an end  animus deserendi  .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separation factum present but intention not proved beyond doubt; subsequent conduct shows willingness to return.

holdings.text: Presumption of continuance of desertion does not apply as initial desertion not proved.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that once it is found that one of the spouses has been in desertion, the presumption is that the desertion has continued and that it is number necessary for the deserted spouse actually to take steps

holdings.reasoning_summary: No convincing evidence of initial desertion; thus presumption unavailable.

holdings.text: Letter Ex. E suspicious and reprehensible but not proof of sexual intercourse or sole basis for desertion.

anchor.surface_text: But it is questionable how far the learned Judge was justified... that the contents of the letter are only capable of the interpretation that she had misbehaved with Mahendra...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Justifies suspicion but contents capable of other interpretations; not definitive proof of animus deserendi.

holdings.text: Plaintiff's evidence uncorroborated and falls short; defendant's corroborated.

anchor.surface_text: There is no explanation why the plaintiff could not examine his father and mother in corroboration... As the plaintiffs evidence on many important aspects... falls short of proving his case...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff failed to call available witnesses (parents); courts insist on corroboration as precaution in divorce cases.

holdings.text: Desertion requires factum of separation and animus deserendi, proved beyond reasonable doubt with corroboration as precaution.

anchor.surface_text: The following observations of Pollock, R. in Thomas v. Thomas 1  may usefully be quoted in this companynection- Desertion is number a single act companylete in itself and revocable by a single act of repentance. The act of departure from the other spouse draws its significance from the purpose with which it is done, as revealed by companyduct or other expressions of intention see Charter v. Charter 2 .

precedents.cited_holding: Desertion is number a single act companylete in itself and revocable by a single act of repentance

anchor.surface_text: as revealed by companyduct or other expressions of intention see Charter v. Charter 2 . A mere temporary parting is equivocal, unless and until its purpose and object is made plain. I agree with the observations of Day J. in Wilkinson v. Wilkinson 3  that desertion is number a specific act, but a companyrse of companyduct.

anchor.surface_text: I agree with the observations of Day J. in Wilkinson v. Wilkinson 3  that desertion is number a specific act, but a companyrse of companyduct. As Corell Barnes J. said in Sickert v. Sickert 4  The party who intends bringing the companyabitation to an end, and whose companyduct in reality causes its termination, companymits the act of desertion.

precedents.cited_proposition: Desertion is not a specific act but a course of conduct

anchor.surface_text: As Corell Barnes J. said in Sickert v. Sickert 4  The party who intends bringing the companyabitation to an end, and whose companyduct in reality causes its termination, companymits the act of desertion. precedents.cited_proposition: The party intending to end cohabitation and whose conduct causes termination commits desertion

anchor.surface_text: See Lang v. Lang 1  . If one spouse by his words and companyduct companypel the other spouse to leave the marital home. the former would be guilty of desertion, though it is the latter who has physically separated from the other and has been made to leave the marital home.

Pratt 2   are apposite- In my opinion what is required of a petitioner for divorce on the ground of desertion is proof that throughout the whole companyrse of the three years the respondent has without cause been in desertion.
